Distance from center of Earth to center of Moon

The instantaneous **Earth–Moon distance**, or **distance to the Moon**, is the distance from the center of [Earth](/wiki/Earth "Earth") to the center of the [Moon](/wiki/Moon "Moon"). In contrast, the **Lunar distance** (**LD** or

Δ

⊕
L

{\\textstyle \\Delta \_{\\oplus L}}

![{\textstyle \Delta _{\oplus L}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/cc4cbdbca7d4fd84bbc4572852e77a36679bc84e)), or **Earth–Moon characteristic distance**, is a [unit of measure](/wiki/Unit_of_measure "Unit of measure") in [astronomy](/wiki/Astronomy "Astronomy"). More technically, it is the [semi\-major axis](/wiki/Semi-major_axis "Semi-major axis") of the geocentric [lunar orbit](/wiki/Orbit_of_the_Moon "Orbit of the Moon"). The lunar distance is on average approximately 385,000 km (239,000 mi), or 1\.28 [light\-seconds](/wiki/Light-second "Light-second"); this is roughly 30 times [Earth's diameter](/wiki/Earth_radius "Earth radius") or 9\.5 times [Earth's circumference](/wiki/Earth%27s_circumference "Earth's circumference"). Around 389 lunar distances make up an AU [astronomical unit](/wiki/Astronomical_unit "Astronomical unit") (roughly the distance from Earth to the Sun).

Lunar distance is commonly used to express the distance to [near\-Earth object](/wiki/Near-Earth_object "Near-Earth object") encounters.[\[1]](#cite_note-NEO-1) Lunar semi\-major axis is an important astronomical datum; the few\-millimeter precision of the range measurements determines semi\-major axis to a few decimeters; it has implications for testing gravitational theories such as [general relativity](/wiki/General_relativity "General relativity") and [\[2]](#cite_note-Relativity-2) and for refining other astronomical values, such as the [mass](/wiki/Earth_mass "Earth mass"),[\[3]](#cite_note-moonbounce-3) [radius](/wiki/Earth_radius "Earth radius"),[\[4]](#cite_note-Fischer-4) and [rotation](/wiki/Earth%27s_rotation "Earth's rotation") of Earth.[\[5]](#cite_note-LLR-5) The measurement is also useful in expressing the [lunar radius](/wiki/Lunar_radius "Lunar radius"), as well as the [distance to the Sun](/wiki/Astronomical_unit "Astronomical unit").

Millimeter\-[precision](/wiki/Accuracy_and_precision "Accuracy and precision") measurements of the lunar distance are made by measuring the time taken for laser beam light to travel between stations on Earth and [retroreflectors](/wiki/Retroreflector "Retroreflector") placed on the Moon. The Moon is spiraling away from Earth at an average rate of 3\.8 cm (1\.5 in) per year, as detected by the [Lunar Laser Ranging experiment](/wiki/Lunar_Laser_Ranging_experiment "Lunar Laser Ranging experiment").[\[6]](#cite_note-drift1-6)[\[7]](#cite_note-drift2-7)[\[8]](#cite_note-drift3-8)

Value
-----

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lunar_distance&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Value")]

Distribution of perigee and apogee between 3000 BC and AD 3000

Because of the influence of the Sun and other perturbations, the Moon's orbit around the Earth is not a precise ellipse. Nevertheless, different methods have been used to define a [semi\-major axis](/wiki/Semi-major_and_semi-minor_axes "Semi-major and semi-minor axes"). [Ernest William Brown](/wiki/Ernest_William_Brown "Ernest William Brown") provided a formula for the [parallax](/wiki/Parallax "Parallax") of the Moon as viewed from opposite sides of the Earth, involving [trigonometric](/wiki/Trigonometric "Trigonometric") terms. This is equivalent to a formula for the inverse of the distance, and the average value of this is the inverse of 384,399 km (238,854 mi).[\[9]](#cite_note-MeeusMorsels1Ch4-9)[\[10]](#cite_note-:1-10) On the other hand, the time\-averaged distance (rather than the inverse of the average inverse distance) between the centers of Earth and the Moon is 385,000\.6 km (239,228\.3 mi). One can also model the orbit as an ellipse that is constantly changing, and in this case one can find a formula for the semi\-major axis, again involving trigonometric terms. The average value by this method is 383,397 km.[\[11]](#cite_note-SimonEtAl-11)

The actual distance varies over the course of the [orbit of the Moon](/wiki/Orbit_of_the_Moon "Orbit of the Moon"). Values at closest approach ([perigee](/wiki/Perigee "Perigee")) or at farthest ([apogee](/wiki/Apogee "Apogee")) are rarer the more extreme they are. The graph at right shows the distribution of perigee and apogee over six thousand years.

[Jean Meeus](/wiki/Jean_Meeus "Jean Meeus") gives the following extreme values for 1500 BC to AD 8000:[\[12]](#cite_note-MeeusMorsels1Ch2-12)

* greatest distance: 406 719\.97 km on January 7, AD 2266
* smallest distance: 356 352\.93 km on November 13, 1054 BC

Variation
---------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lunar_distance&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Variation")]
The instantaneous lunar distance is constantly changing. The actual distance between the Moon and Earth can change as quickly as 75 meters per second,[\[20]](#cite_note-millimeter_challenge-20) or more than 1,000 km (620 mi) in just 6 hours, due to its non\-circular orbit.[\[21]](#cite_note-Zuluaga-21) There are other effects that also influence the lunar distance. Some factors include:

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Moon_distance_range_to_scale.svg/800px-Moon_distance_range_to_scale.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Moon_distance_range_to_scale.svg "Minimum, mean and maximum distances of the Moon from Earth with its angular diameter as seen from Earth's surface, to scale")Minimum, mean and maximum distances of the Moon from Earth with its angular diameter as seen from Earth's surface, to scale

Lunar distance when perigee is at syzygy (full moon or new moon, in blue) or at half moon (red). The horizontal lines (extending exactly half a mean anomalistic month to each side of perigee) are the respective averages over one mean anomalistic month, and are almost identical.

This shows that the smallest perigee occurs at either new moon or full moon (ca 356870 km), as does the greatest apogee (ca 406079 km), whereas the greatest perigee will be around half\-moon (ca 370180 km), as will be the smallest apogee (ca 404593 km). The exact values will be slightly different due to other terms. Twice in every [full moon cycle](/wiki/Full_moon_cycle "Full moon cycle") of about 411 days there will be a minimal perigee and a maximal apogee, separated by two weeks, and a maximal perigee and a minimal apogee, also separated by two weeks.

### Perturbations and eccentricity

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lunar_distance&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Perturbations and eccentricity")]
The distance to the Moon can be measured to an accuracy of 2 mm over a 1\-hour sampling period,[\[22]](#cite_note-APOLLO_Analysis-22) which results in an overall uncertainty of a decimeter for the semi\-major axis. However, due to [its elliptical orbit](/wiki/Orbit_of_the_Moon "Orbit of the Moon") with varying eccentricity, the instantaneous distance varies with monthly periodicity. Furthermore, the distance is perturbed by the gravitational effects of various astronomical bodies – most significantly the Sun and less so Venus and Jupiter. Other forces responsible for minute perturbations are: gravitational attraction to other planets in the Solar System and to asteroids; tidal forces; and relativistic effects.[\[23]](#cite_note-integration-23)[\[24]](#cite_note-24) The effect of [radiation pressure](/wiki/Yarkovsky_effect "Yarkovsky effect") from the Sun contributes an amount of ±3\.6 mm to the lunar distance.[\[22]](#cite_note-APOLLO_Analysis-22)

Although the instantaneous uncertainty is a few millimeters, the measured lunar distance can change by more than 30,000 km (19,000 mi) from the mean value throughout a typical month. These perturbations are well understood[\[25]](#cite_note-DE431-25) and the lunar distance can be accurately modeled over thousands of years.[\[23]](#cite_note-integration-23)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Moon-Earth_distance%2C_Moon_phases.gif/660px-Moon-Earth_distance%2C_Moon_phases.gif)](/wiki/File:Moon-Earth_distance,_Moon_phases.gif)

The Moon's distance from the [Earth](/wiki/Earth "Earth") and [Moon phases](/wiki/Lunar_phase "Lunar phase") in 2014\.
Moon phases: 0 (1\) – [new moon](/wiki/New_moon "New moon"), 0\.25 – first quarter, 0\.5 – [full moon](/wiki/Full_moon "Full moon"), 0\.75 – last quarter.

### Tidal dissipation

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lunar_distance&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Tidal dissipation")]
Through the action of [tidal forces](/wiki/Tidal_forces "Tidal forces"), the [angular momentum](/wiki/Angular_momentum "Angular momentum") of Earth's rotation is slowly being transferred to the Moon's orbit.[\[26]](#cite_note-paleoceanography-26) The result is that Earth's rate of spin is gradually decreasing (at a rate of 2\.4 milliseconds/century),[\[27]](#cite_note-space.com-27)[\[28]](#cite_note-:0-28)[\[29]](#cite_note-29)[\[30]](#cite_note-30) and the lunar orbit is gradually expanding. The rate of recession is 3\.830±0\.008 cm per year.[\[25]](#cite_note-DE431-25)[\[28]](#cite_note-:0-28) However, it is believed that this rate has recently increased, as a rate of 3\.8 cm/year would imply that the Moon is only 1\.5 billion years old, whereas scientific consensus supports an age of about 4 billion years.[\[31]](#cite_note-Precambrian-31) It is also believed that this anomalously high rate of recession may continue to accelerate.[\[32]](#cite_note-Lunar_Orbit_Evolution-32)

Theoretically, the lunar distance will continue to increase until the Earth and Moon become [tidally locked](/wiki/Tidal_locking "Tidal locking"), as are Pluto and [Charon](/wiki/Charon_(moon) "Charon (moon)"). This would occur when the duration of the lunar orbital period equals the rotational period of Earth, which is estimated to be 47 Earth days. The two bodies would then be at equilibrium, and no further rotational energy would be exchanged. However, models predict that 50 billion years would be required to achieve this configuration,[\[33]](#cite_note-tidal_lock-33) which is significantly longer than the [expected lifetime of the Solar System](/wiki/Red_giant#The_Sun_as_a_red_giant "Red giant").

### Orbital history

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lunar_distance&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Orbital history")]
Laser measurements show that the average lunar distance is increasing, which implies that the Moon was closer in the past, and that Earth's days were shorter. Fossil studies of mollusk shells from the [Campanian](/wiki/Campanian "Campanian") era (80 million years ago) show that there were 372 days (of 23 h 33 min) per year during that time, which implies that the lunar distance was about 60\.05 [R🜨](/wiki/Earth_radius "Earth radius") (383,000 km or 238,000 mi).[\[26]](#cite_note-paleoceanography-26) There is geological evidence that the average lunar distance was about 52 R🜨 (332,000 km or 205,000 mi) during the [Precambrian Era](/wiki/Precambrian "Precambrian"); 2500 million years [BP](/wiki/Before_Present "Before Present").[\[31]](#cite_note-Precambrian-31)

The widely accepted [giant impact hypothesis](/wiki/Origin_of_the_Moon "Origin of the Moon") states that the Moon was created as a result of a catastrophic impact between Earth and another planet, resulting in a re\-accumulation of fragments at an initial distance of 3\.8 R🜨 (24,000 km or 15,000 mi).[\[34]](#cite_note-Impact-34) This theory assumes the initial impact to have occurred 4\.5 billion years ago.[\[35]](#cite_note-TheiaPothesis-35)

History of measurement
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lunar_distance&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: History of measurement")]
Until the late 1950s all measurements of lunar distance were based on [optical angular measurements](/w/index.php?title=Optical_angular_measurement&action=edit&redlink=1 "Optical angular measurement (page does not exist)"): the earliest accurate measurement was by [Hipparchus](/wiki/Hipparchus "Hipparchus") in the 2nd century BC. The space age marked a turning point when the precision of this value was much improved. During the 1950s and 1960s, there were experiments using radar, lasers, and spacecraft, conducted with the benefit of computer processing and modeling.[\[36]](#cite_note-DE_102-36)

Some historically significant or otherwise interesting methods of determining the lunar distance:

### Parallax

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lunar_distance&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Parallax")]
The oldest method of determining the lunar distance involved measuring the angle between the Moon and a chosen reference point from multiple locations, simultaneously. The synchronization can be coordinated by making measurements at a pre\-determined time, or during an event which is observable to all parties. Before accurate mechanical chronometers, the synchronization event was typically a [lunar eclipse](/wiki/Lunar_eclipse "Lunar eclipse"), or the moment when the Moon crossed the meridian (if the observers shared the same longitude). This measurement technique is known as [lunar parallax](/wiki/Parallax#Lunar_parallax "Parallax").

For increased accuracy, the measured angle can be adjusted to account for refraction and distortion of light passing through the atmosphere.

#### Lunar eclipse

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lunar_distance&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Lunar eclipse")]
Early attempts to measure the distance to the Moon exploited observations of a lunar eclipse combined with knowledge of Earth's radius and an understanding that the Sun is much further than the Moon. By observing the geometry of a lunar eclipse, the lunar distance can be calculated using [trigonometry](/wiki/Trigonometry "Trigonometry").

The earliest accounts of attempts to measure the lunar distance using this technique were by Greek astronomer and mathematician [Aristarchus of Samos](/wiki/Aristarchus_of_Samos "Aristarchus of Samos") in the 4th century BC[\[37]](#cite_note-Gutzwiller-37) and later by [Hipparchus](/wiki/Hipparchus "Hipparchus"), whose calculations produced a result of 59–67 R🜨 (376000–427000 km or 233000–265000 mi).[\[38]](#cite_note-transit-38) This method later found its way into the work of [Ptolemy](/wiki/Ptolemy "Ptolemy"),[\[39]](#cite_note-Measuring_the_Universe-39) who produced a result of 64\+1⁄6 R🜨 (409000 km or 253000 mi) at its farthest point.[\[40]](#cite_note-Helden-40)

#### Meridian crossing

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lunar_distance&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Meridian crossing")]
An expedition by French astronomer [A.C.D. Crommelin](/wiki/Andrew_Claude_de_la_Cherois_Crommelin "Andrew Claude de la Cherois Crommelin") observed lunar [meridian transits](/wiki/Meridian_transit "Meridian transit") on the same night from two different locations. Careful measurements from 1905 to 1910 measured the angle of elevation at the moment when a specific lunar crater ([Mösting A](/wiki/M%C3%B6sting_(crater) "Mösting (crater)")) crossed the local meridian, from stations at [Greenwich](/wiki/Greenwich "Greenwich") and at [Cape of Good Hope](/wiki/Cape_of_Good_Hope "Cape of Good Hope").[\[41]](#cite_note-Commelin-41) A distance was calculated with an uncertainty of 30 km, and this remained the definitive lunar distance value for the next half century.

#### Occultations

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lunar_distance&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Occultations")]
By recording the instant when the Moon [occults](/wiki/Occultation "Occultation") a background star, (or similarly, measuring the angle between the Moon and a background star at a predetermined moment) the lunar distance can be determined, as long as the measurements are taken from multiple locations of known separation.

Astronomers [O'Keefe](/wiki/John_A._O%27Keefe_(astronomer) "John A. O'Keefe (astronomer)") and Anderson calculated the lunar distance by observing four occultations from nine locations in 1952\.[\[42]](#cite_note-O'Keefe-42) They calculated a semi\-major axis of 384407.6±4\.7 km (238,859\.8 ± 2\.9 mi). This value was refined in 1962 by [Irene Fischer](/wiki/Irene_Fischer "Irene Fischer"), who incorporated updated [geodetic](/wiki/Geodesy "Geodesy") data to produce a value of 384403.7±2 km (238,857\.4 ± 1 mi).[\[4]](#cite_note-Fischer-4)

### Radar

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lunar_distance&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Radar")]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/First_radar_return_from_the_Moon_-_Project_Diana_1946.jpg/220px-First_radar_return_from_the_Moon_-_Project_Diana_1946.jpg)](/wiki/File:First_radar_return_from_the_Moon_-_Project_Diana_1946.jpg)

Oscilloscope display showing the radar signal.[\[43]](#cite_note-Gootée-43) The large pulse on the left is the transmitted signal, the small pulse on the right is the return signal from the Moon. The horizontal axis is time, but is calibrated in miles. It can be seen that the measured range is 238,000 mi (383,000 km), approximately the distance from the Earth to the Moon.

The distance to the moon was measured by means of radar first in 1946 as part of [Project Diana](/wiki/Project_Diana "Project Diana").[\[44]](#cite_note-SciHi_Blog_2022-44)

Later, an experiment was conducted in 1957 at the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory that used the echo from radar signals to determine the Earth\-Moon distance. Radar pulses lasting 2 μs were broadcast from a 50\-foot (15 m) diameter radio dish. After the radio waves echoed off the surface of the Moon, the return signal was detected and the delay time measured. From that measurement, the distance could be calculated. In practice, however, the [signal\-to\-noise ratio](/wiki/Signal-to-noise_ratio "Signal-to-noise ratio") was so low that an accurate measurement could not be reliably produced.[\[45]](#cite_note-Radar1-45)

The experiment was repeated in 1958 at the [Royal Radar Establishment](/wiki/Royal_Radar_Establishment "Royal Radar Establishment"), in England. Radar pulses lasting 5 μs were transmitted with a peak power of 2 megawatts, at a repetition rate of 260 pulses per second. After the radio waves echoed off the surface of the Moon, the return signal was detected and the delay time measured. Multiple signals were added together to obtain a reliable signal by superimposing oscilloscope traces onto photographic film. From the measurements, the distance was calculated with an uncertainty of 1\.25 km (0\.777 mi).[\[46]](#cite_note-Radar2-46)

These initial experiments were intended to be proof\-of\-concept experiments and only lasted one day. Follow\-on experiments lasting one month produced a semi\-major axis of 384402±1\.2 km (238,856 ± 0\.75 mi),[\[47]](#cite_note-Radar3-47) which was the most precise measurement of the lunar distance at the time.

### Laser ranging

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lunar_distance&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Laser ranging")]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Apollo_11_Lunar_Laser_Ranging_Experiment.jpg/220px-Apollo_11_Lunar_Laser_Ranging_Experiment.jpg)](/wiki/File:Apollo_11_Lunar_Laser_Ranging_Experiment.jpg)

Lunar Laser Ranging Experiment from the Apollo 11 mission

An experiment which measured the round\-trip [time of flight](/wiki/Time_of_flight "Time of flight") of laser pulses reflected directly off the surface of the Moon was performed in 1962, by a team from [Massachusetts Institute of Technology](/wiki/Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology "Massachusetts Institute of Technology"), and a Soviet team at the [Crimean Astrophysical Observatory](/wiki/Crimean_Astrophysical_Observatory "Crimean Astrophysical Observatory").[\[48]](#cite_note-Lunar_Laser_Ranging-48)

During the Apollo missions in 1969, astronauts placed [retroreflectors](/wiki/Retroreflectors "Retroreflectors") on the surface of the Moon for the purpose of refining the accuracy and precision of this technique. The measurements are ongoing and involve multiple laser facilities. The instantaneous precision of the [Lunar Laser Ranging experiments](/wiki/Lunar_Laser_Ranging_experiment "Lunar Laser Ranging experiment") can achieve small millimeter resolution, and is the most reliable method of determining the lunar distance. The semi\-major axis is determined to be 384,399\.0 km.[\[10]](#cite_note-:1-10)

### Amateur astronomers and citizen scientists

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lunar_distance&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Amateur astronomers and citizen scientists")]

Please [help improve it](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Lunar_distance&action=edit) by rewriting it in a **[balanced fashion](/wiki/Wikipedia:Neutral_point_of_view#Balance "Wikipedia:Neutral point of view")** that contextualizes different points of view. *(September 2020)* *([Learn how and when to remove this message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))* |
| --- | --- |

Due to the modern accessibility of accurate timing devices, high resolution digital cameras, [GPS](/wiki/GPS "GPS") receivers, powerful computers and near\-instantaneous communication, it has become possible for amateur astronomers to make high accuracy measurements of the lunar distance.

On May 23, 2007, digital photographs of the Moon during a [near\-occultation](/wiki/Occultation "Occultation") of [Regulus](/wiki/Regulus "Regulus") were taken from two locations, in Greece and England. By measuring the [parallax](/wiki/Parallax "Parallax") between the Moon and the chosen background star, the lunar distance was calculated.[\[49]](#cite_note-Citizen1-49)

A more ambitious project called the "Aristarchus Campaign" was conducted during the [lunar eclipse](/wiki/Lunar_eclipse "Lunar eclipse") of 15 April 2014\.[\[21]](#cite_note-Zuluaga-21) During this event, participants were invited to record a series of five digital photographs from moonrise until [culmination](/wiki/Culmination "Culmination") (the point of greatest altitude).

The method took advantage of the fact that the Moon is actually closest to an observer when it is at its highest point in the sky, compared to when it is on the horizon. Although it appears that the Moon is biggest when it is near the horizon, the opposite is true. This phenomenon is known as the [Moon illusion](/wiki/Moon_illusion "Moon illusion"). The reason for the difference in distance is that the distance from the center of the Moon to the center of the Earth is nearly constant throughout the night, but an observer on the surface of Earth is actually 1 Earth radius from the center of Earth. This offset brings them closest to the Moon when it is overhead.

Modern cameras have achieved a resolution capable of capturing the Moon with enough precision to detect and measure this tiny variation in apparent size. The results of this experiment were calculated as LD \= 60\.51\+3\.91
−4\.19 R🜨. The accepted value for that night was 60\.61 R🜨, which implied a 3% accuracy. The benefit of this method is that the only measuring equipment needed is a modern digital camera (equipped with an accurate clock, and a GPS receiver).

Other experimental methods of measuring the lunar distance that can be performed by amateur astronomers involve:

* Taking pictures of the Moon before it enters the [penumbra](/wiki/Umbra,_penumbra_and_antumbra "Umbra, penumbra and antumbra") and after it is completely eclipsed.
* Measuring, as precisely as possible, the time of the eclipse contacts.
* Taking good pictures of the partial eclipse when the shape and size of the Earth shadow are clearly visible.
* Taking a picture of the Moon including, in the same field of view, [Spica](/wiki/Spica "Spica") and [Mars](/wiki/Mars "Mars") – from various locations.

**Eliud Kipchoge** [EGH](/wiki/Order_of_the_Golden_Heart_(Kenya) "Order of the Golden Heart (Kenya)") (born 5 November 1984\) is a Kenyan [long\-distance runner](/wiki/Long-distance_runner "Long-distance runner") who competes in the [marathon](/wiki/Marathon "Marathon") and formerly specialized in the [5000 metres](/wiki/5000_metres "5000 metres"). Kipchoge is the [2016](/wiki/Athletics_at_the_2016_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_marathon "Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's marathon") and [2020](/wiki/Athletics_at_the_2020_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_marathon "Athletics at the 2020 Summer Olympics – Men's marathon") Olympic marathon champion, and was the [world record](/wiki/Marathon_world_record_progression "Marathon world record progression") holder in the marathon from 2018 to 2023,[\[3]](#cite_note-3) until that record was broken by [Kelvin Kiptum](/wiki/Kelvin_Kiptum "Kelvin Kiptum") at the [2023 Chicago Marathon](/wiki/2023_Chicago_Marathon "2023 Chicago Marathon"). Kipchoge has run 3 of the 10 fastest marathons in history.[\[4]](#cite_note-4)

Kipchoge claimed his first individual world championship title in 2003 by winning the junior race at the [World Cross Country Championships](/wiki/2003_IAAF_World_Cross_Country_Championships "2003 IAAF World Cross Country Championships") and setting a [world junior record](/wiki/List_of_junior_world_records_in_athletics "List of junior world records in athletics") for the 5000 m. At the age of eighteen, he became the senior 5000 m world champion at the [2003 World Championships](/wiki/2003_World_Championships_in_Athletics "2003 World Championships in Athletics") with a championship record, then followed by an Olympic bronze for Kenya in [2004](/wiki/Athletics_at_the_2004_Summer_Olympics "Athletics at the 2004 Summer Olympics") and a bronze at the [2006 World Indoor Championships](/wiki/2006_IAAF_World_Indoor_Championships "2006 IAAF World Indoor Championships"). A five\-time [World Championship 5000 m](/wiki/5000_metres_at_the_World_Championships_in_Athletics "5000 metres at the World Championships in Athletics") finalist, Kipchoge took silver medals at the [2007 World Championships](/wiki/2007_World_Championships_in_Athletics "2007 World Championships in Athletics"), [2008 Beijing Olympics](/wiki/Athletics_at_the_2008_Summer_Olympics "Athletics at the 2008 Summer Olympics"), and [2010 Commonwealth Games](/wiki/Athletics_at_the_2010_Commonwealth_Games "Athletics at the 2010 Commonwealth Games").

He switched to [road running](/wiki/Road_running "Road running") in 2012 and made the second\-fastest [half marathon](/wiki/Half_marathon "Half marathon") debut ever, at 59:25\. In his marathon debut, he won the 2013 [Hamburg Marathon](/wiki/Hamburg_Marathon "Hamburg Marathon") in a course record time. His first victory at a [World Marathon Major](/wiki/World_Marathon_Major "World Marathon Major") came at the [Chicago Marathon](/wiki/Chicago_Marathon "Chicago Marathon") in 2014, and he went on to become series champion a record five times – for 2016, 2017, 2018, 2019 and 2022\. He has won the [London Marathon](/wiki/London_Marathon "London Marathon") a record four times and also holds the record for most [Berlin Marathon](/wiki/Berlin_Marathon "Berlin Marathon") wins with five, his latest coming in September 2023\. With 15 victories out of his 18 marathons, Kipchoge's only losses have been a second\-place finish behind [Wilson Kipsang Kiprotich](/wiki/Wilson_Kipsang_Kiprotich "Wilson Kipsang Kiprotich") at the [2013 Berlin Marathon](/wiki/2013_Berlin_Marathon "2013 Berlin Marathon"), where Kipsang broke the world record, an eighth\-place finish at the [2020 London Marathon](/wiki/2020_London_Marathon "2020 London Marathon") and a sixth place in his debut at the [Boston Marathon](/wiki/Boston_Marathon "Boston Marathon") in [2023](/wiki/2023_Boston_Marathon "2023 Boston Marathon").[\[5]](#cite_note-News-5)[\[6]](#cite_note-BBC_Sport-6)[\[7]](#cite_note-runningmagazine.ca-7) Kipchoge's last world record run broke by 30 seconds his own 2018 world record, which was in turn a 78\-second improvement over the existing best, the greatest improvement in a marathon world record time since 1967\.

On 12 October 2019, Kipchoge ran the marathon distance for the [Ineos 1:59 Challenge](/wiki/Ineos_1:59_Challenge "Ineos 1:59 Challenge") in [Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna"), achieving a time of 1:59:40\.2, becoming the first person in recorded history to do a sub\-two\-hour marathon.[\[8]](#cite_note-8) The run did not count as a new marathon record, as standard competition rules for pacing and fluids were not followed, and it was not an open event.[\[9]](#cite_note-9)[\[10]](#cite_note-10)[\[11]](#cite_note-11)

Kipchoge was appointed [Elder of the Order of the Golden Heart](/wiki/Order_of_the_Golden_Heart_(Kenya) "Order of the Golden Heart (Kenya)") by President [Uhuru Kenyatta](/wiki/Uhuru_Kenyatta "Uhuru Kenyatta") on 20 October 2019 in recognition of his sub\-two\-hour marathon.[\[12]](#cite_note-12) He was also named the 2019 [BBC World Sport Star of the Year](/wiki/BBC_Sports_Personality_World_Sport_Star_of_the_Year "BBC Sports Personality World Sport Star of the Year"). In 2023 he was awarded the [Princess of Asturias Award](/wiki/Princess_of_Asturias_Award "Princess of Asturias Award") in the category "Sports".[\[13]](#cite_note-Princess_of_Asturias_Award_2023-13)

Personal life
-------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Eliud_Kipchoge&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Personal life")]
Kipchoge was born on 5 November 1984 in Kapsisiywa, [Nandi County](/wiki/Nandi_County "Nandi County"), in Kenya. He graduated from the Kaptel Secondary School in Nandi County in 1999 but did not run seriously or as a profession then.[\[14]](#cite_note-WAprofile-14)[\[15]](#cite_note-15) He ran three kilometres (2 mi) to school on a daily basis.[\[16]](#cite_note-16) Kipchoge was raised by a single mother (a teacher), and only knew his father from pictures. He is the youngest of four children. He met his trainer [Patrick Sang](/wiki/Patrick_Sang "Patrick Sang") (a former Olympic medalist in the [steeplechase](/wiki/Steeplechase_(athletics) "Steeplechase (athletics)")) in 2001 at the age of 16\.[\[17]](#cite_note-nytimes201809-17)

Kipchoge's wife and three children live in [Eldoret](/wiki/Eldoret "Eldoret"), Kenya.[\[18]](#cite_note-auto1-18)[\[19]](#cite_note-19) He lives and trains in [Kaptagat](/wiki/Kaptagat "Kaptagat"), 30 km (19 miles) from Eldoret.[\[20]](#cite_note-20) He is a devout [Catholic](/wiki/Catholic_Church "Catholic Church").[\[21]](#cite_note-21)

Career
------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Eliud_Kipchoge&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Career")]
### 2002–2004

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Eliud_Kipchoge&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: 2002–2004")]
In 2002, he won at the Kenyan trials for the [2002 IAAF World Cross Country Championships](/wiki/2002_IAAF_World_Cross_Country_Championships "2002 IAAF World Cross Country Championships") junior race. At the World Cross Country Championships, held in [Dublin](/wiki/Dublin "Dublin"), Kipchoge finished fifth in the individual race and was part of the Kenyan junior team that won gold. Kipchoge also won the 5000 metres race at the Kenyan trial for the [2002 World Junior Championships in Athletics](/wiki/2002_World_Junior_Championships_in_Athletics "2002 World Junior Championships in Athletics") but fell ill and missed the championships. He won the junior race at the [2003 IAAF World Cross Country Championships](/wiki/2003_IAAF_World_Cross_Country_Championships "2003 IAAF World Cross Country Championships").

He set a [world junior record](/wiki/List_of_world_junior_records_in_athletics "List of world junior records in athletics") in the 5000 m at the 2003 [Bislett Games](/wiki/Bislett_Games "Bislett Games"), running a time of 12:52\.61 minutes. This stood as the world and [African junior record](/wiki/List_of_African_junior_records_in_athletics "List of African junior records in athletics") until 2012 when it was improved to 12:47\.53 minutes by [Hagos Gebrhiwet](/wiki/Hagos_Gebrhiwet "Hagos Gebrhiwet") of Ethiopia.[\[22]](#cite_note-22)

Kipchoge won a gold medal at the [5000 m](/wiki/2003_World_Championships_in_Athletics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_5000_metres "2003 World Championships in Athletics – Men's 5000 metres") final at the [2003 World Championships in Paris](/wiki/2003_World_Championships_in_Athletics "2003 World Championships in Athletics"), outsprinting runner\-up [Hicham El Guerrouj](/wiki/Hicham_El_Guerrouj "Hicham El Guerrouj"), the world record holder in the [1500 metres](/wiki/1500_metres "1500 metres") and [mile](/wiki/Mile_run "Mile run"), by four\-hundredths of a second in 12:52\.79\.[\[23]](#cite_note-23)

In July, he participated in the Golden League 2004 Roma Meeting. In the 5000 m event, he dipped first among the starters with 12:46\.53, which made him the sixth\-fastest ever in the event.[\[24]](#cite_note-24)

In 2004, Kipchoge won a bronze medal at the [5000 m final](/wiki/Athletics_at_the_2004_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_5000_metres "Athletics at the 2004 Summer Olympics – Men's 5000 metres") at the [2004 Athens Olympics](/wiki/2004_Summer_Olympics "2004 Summer Olympics"), behind El Guerrouj and [Kenenisa Bekele](/wiki/Kenenisa_Bekele "Kenenisa Bekele").[\[25]](#cite_note-25) He also won the [Trofeo Alasport](/wiki/Trofeo_Alasport "Trofeo Alasport") cross country race earlier that season.

### 2006

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Eliud_Kipchoge&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: 2006")]
Kipchoge won the bronze in the 3000 metres indoor at the [2006 World Championships](/wiki/2006_IAAF_World_Indoor_Championships "2006 IAAF World Indoor Championships") in Moscow.

At the end of the year, Kipchoge won the [San Silvestre Vallecana](/wiki/San_Silvestre_Vallecana "San Silvestre Vallecana") New Year's Eve 10 km road race in a time of 26:54 minutes, which beat his own course record by 40 seconds. This time was also better than the 10K road world record at the time but was run on a downhill course.[\[26]](#cite_note-26)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Osaka07_D6A_M5000M_Heat2-2.jpg/220px-Osaka07_D6A_M5000M_Heat2-2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Osaka07_D6A_M5000M_Heat2-2.jpg)

Kipchoge (third from the right) during the 5000 m heat at the [2007 World Championships](/wiki/2007_World_Championships_in_Athletics "2007 World Championships in Athletics") in [Osaka](/wiki/Osaka "Osaka"). He won a silver medal in the final.

### 2007

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Eliud_Kipchoge&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: 2007")]
Kipchoge won a silver medal at the 5000 m final of the [2007 World Championships](/wiki/2007_World_Championships_in_Athletics "2007 World Championships in Athletics") at [Osaka](/wiki/Osaka "Osaka") in 13:46\.00, behind [Bernard Lagat](/wiki/Bernard_Lagat "Bernard Lagat") (13:45\.87\).[\[27]](#cite_note-27)

### 2008

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Eliud_Kipchoge&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: 2008")]
During the [2008 Olympics](/wiki/Athletics_at_the_2008_Summer_Olympics "Athletics at the 2008 Summer Olympics") held in Beijing, China, Kipchoge won a silver medal in the 5000 m event with a time of 13:02\.80; although better than the previous Olympic record of 13:05\.59, it was not enough to match Kenenisa Bekele's pace, who won the gold medal for this race.[\[28]](#cite_note-28) On the circuit, he won the [Great Yorkshire Run](/wiki/Great_Yorkshire_Run "Great Yorkshire Run") 10K and [Campaccio](/wiki/Campaccio "Campaccio") Cross Country that year.

### 2009

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Eliud_Kipchoge&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: 2009")]
He failed to reach the podium at the [2009 World Championships in Athletics](/wiki/2009_World_Championships_in_Athletics "2009 World Championships in Athletics"), finishing in fifth place. He also finished ninth in the 3000 m at the [2009 IAAF World Athletics Final](/wiki/2009_IAAF_World_Athletics_Final "2009 IAAF World Athletics Final").

### 2010–2011

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Eliud_Kipchoge&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: 2010–2011")]
He made his debut on the [2010 IAAF Diamond League](/wiki/2010_IAAF_Diamond_League "2010 IAAF Diamond League") by winning the 5000 m [Qatar Athletic Super Grand Prix](/wiki/Qatar_Athletic_Super_Grand_Prix "Qatar Athletic Super Grand Prix") in a meet record time.[\[29]](#cite_note-29)

Kipchoge then entered the Carlsbad 5000 in California, United States. The Carlsbad 5 km road race is the venue for the world's best times for a 5k road race for men and women, respectively. The fastest to cover the track was Sammy Kipketer in 2000, with 12:59\.52 min.[\[30]](#cite_note-30) Kipchoge made a world best attempt, and although he won the race, weather affected his chances, and he finished in 13:11, the fourth\-fastest ever for the course up to that point in time.[\[31]](#cite_note-31)

In the first athletics final of the [2010 Commonwealth Games](/wiki/2010_Commonwealth_Games "2010 Commonwealth Games"), he attempted to win the 5000 m Commonwealth title. Ugandan runner [Moses Kipsiro](/wiki/Moses_Kipsiro "Moses Kipsiro") held a slender lead over him in the race's final stages, and Kipchoge ended up in second place, taking the silver medal some seven\-hundredths of a second behind.[\[32]](#cite_note-32)[\[33]](#cite_note-33) He flew back to Europe immediately after to take part in the [Belgrade Race through History](/wiki/Belgrade_Race_through_History "Belgrade Race through History") the following day. His shoe fell off in the first kilometre, and, after putting it back on, he made up much ground on the field to eventually take second place two seconds behind [Josphat Menjo](/wiki/Josphat_Menjo "Josphat Menjo").[\[34]](#cite_note-34)

At the start of 2011, he won the short race at the [Great Edinburgh Cross Country](/wiki/Great_Edinburgh_Cross_Country "Great Edinburgh Cross Country"), ahead of [Asbel Kiprop](/wiki/Asbel_Kiprop "Asbel Kiprop").[\[35]](#cite_note-35) He attempted to retain his title at the Carlsbad 5000 in April but came a close second behind [Dejen Gebremeskel](/wiki/Dejen_Gebremeskel "Dejen Gebremeskel").[\[36]](#cite_note-36) In May he raced the [3000 metres](/wiki/3000_metres "3000 metres") (finished third) in Doha, with a time of 7:27\.66 and ranked him as the 12th\-fastest at the distance up to this point.[\[37]](#cite_note-37) Kipchoge was chosen to represent Kenya at the [2011 World Championships in Athletics](/wiki/2011_World_Championships_in_Athletics "2011 World Championships in Athletics") and reached the 5000 m final for the fifth consecutive time, although he only managed seventh place on this occasion.

### 2012

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Eliud_Kipchoge&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: 2012")]
Kipchoge returned to the Edinburgh Cross Country in 2012, but this time he finished third behind Asbel Kiprop and Britain's [Jonathan Hay](/wiki/Jonathan_Hay_(athlete) "Jonathan Hay (athlete)").[\[38]](#cite_note-38) He was also third at the [Carlsbad 5000](/wiki/Carlsbad_5000 "Carlsbad 5000") in March.[\[39]](#cite_note-39) He attempted to gain a place on the 10,000 m Olympic team at the [Prefontaine Classic](/wiki/Prefontaine_Classic "Prefontaine Classic"), but fell back in the late stages of the Kenyan trial race, finishing seventh.[\[40]](#cite_note-40) A seventh\-place finish in the Kenyan 5000 m trial race meant he would not make a third consecutive Olympic team.[\[41]](#cite_note-41)

He made his [half marathon](/wiki/Half_marathon "Half marathon") debut in the [Lille Half Marathon](/wiki/Lille_Half_Marathon "Lille Half Marathon").[\[42]](#cite_note-42) The run was won by a new course record time of 59:05 (previously 59:36 by ilahun Regassa set in 2008\) by Ezekiel Chebii (former pb 59:22\), trailed by Bernard Koech 59:10, and Kipchoge earned a third place with 59:25\. His time of 59:25 became the second fastest Half Marathon debut, only second to Moses Mosop's 59:20 in Milan in 2010\.[\[43]](#cite_note-43)

On 6 October 2012, Kipchoge ran at the [2012 IAAF World Half Marathon Championships](/wiki/2012_IAAF_World_Half_Marathon_Championships "2012 IAAF World Half Marathon Championships") in [Kavarna](/wiki/Kavarna "Kavarna"), Bulgaria. [Zersenay Tadese](/wiki/Zersenay_Tadese "Zersenay Tadese") of Eritrea won in 1:00:19 and Kipchoge placed sixth in 1:01:52\.[\[44]](#cite_note-44)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Wilson_Kipsang_Kiprotich_running_world_record_at_Berlin_marathon_2013.jpg/220px-Wilson_Kipsang_Kiprotich_running_world_record_at_Berlin_marathon_2013.jpg)](/wiki/File:Wilson_Kipsang_Kiprotich_running_world_record_at_Berlin_marathon_2013.jpg)

Wilson Kipsang (front) and Kipchoge (behind) running in the [2013 Berlin Marathon](/wiki/2013_Berlin_Marathon "2013 Berlin Marathon") in which Kipsang set the world record with 2:03:23 and Kipchoge, racing in his second marathon, finished second, 42 seconds later.

### 2013

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Eliud_Kipchoge&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: 2013")]
Kipchoge opened his 2013 season with a win at the [Barcelona Half Marathon](/wiki/Barcelona_Half_Marathon "Barcelona Half Marathon") in a time of one hour and four seconds.[\[45]](#cite_note-45) Making his [marathon](/wiki/Marathon "Marathon") debut in April, he demonstrated a smooth transition to the longer distance by taking the [Hamburg Marathon](/wiki/Hamburg_Marathon "Hamburg Marathon") title with a run of 2:05:30 hours, beating the field by over two minutes and setting a new course record.[\[46]](#cite_note-46) In August 2013, he won the Half Marathon of [Klagenfurt](/wiki/Klagenfurt "Klagenfurt") in 1:01:02 minutes.[\[47]](#cite_note-47)

Then, he raced in the [2013 Berlin Marathon](/wiki/2013_Berlin_Marathon "2013 Berlin Marathon") and finished second in 2:04:05, the fifth\-fastest time in history, in his second\-ever marathon,[\[48]](#cite_note-48) behind [Wilson Kipsang](/wiki/Wilson_Kipsang_Kiprotich "Wilson Kipsang Kiprotich"), who set a new marathon world record with 2:03:23\. Third place went to [Geoffrey Kamworor](/wiki/Geoffrey_Kamworor "Geoffrey Kamworor") of Kenya with 2:06:26\.[\[6]](#cite_note-BBC_Sport-6) This was the ninth world record set at the Berlin Marathon.[\[49]](#cite_note-BerlinRecords-49)

### 2015

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Eliud_Kipchoge&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: 2015")]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/2015-04-26_RK_London_Marathon_0137_%2819952962904%29.jpg/220px-2015-04-26_RK_London_Marathon_0137_%2819952962904%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:2015-04-26_RK_London_Marathon_0137_(19952962904).jpg)

Kipchoge races in the [2015 London Marathon](/wiki/2015_London_Marathon "2015 London Marathon").

On 2 February, Kipchoge participated in the Ras al\-Khaimah Half Marathon. He placed sixth with a time of 1:00:50\. The run was won by Mosinet Geremew (Ethiopia) in 1:00:05\.[\[50]](#cite_note-50) Kipchoge ran 2:04:42 to win the [2015 London Marathon](/wiki/2015_London_Marathon "2015 London Marathon") in April. He also won the [2015 Berlin Marathon](/wiki/2015_Berlin_Marathon "2015 Berlin Marathon") later in the year. His win and then\-personal best time (2:04:00\) occurred even though his shoes malfunctioned, causing his insoles to flap out of both shoes from 10 km onward; rather than risk time lost from an adjustment, he finished the race with bloodied, blistered feet.[\[51]](#cite_note-51)

### 2016

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Eliud_Kipchoge&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: 2016")]
In April, Kipchoge won the [2016 London Marathon](/wiki/2016_London_Marathon "2016 London Marathon") for the second consecutive year in a time of 2:03:05\.[\[52]](#cite_note-52) His performance broke the course record in London and became the second\-fastest marathon time in history, missing [Dennis Kimetto](/wiki/Dennis_Kimetto "Dennis Kimetto")'s world record by 8 seconds.[\[53]](#cite_note-53)

**Rio Olympic Games**

As the prerace favourite, during the [2016 Rio Summer Olympics](/wiki/Athletics_at_the_2016_Summer_Olympics "Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics"), Kipchoge gained a gold medal in the [marathon](/wiki/Athletics_at_the_2016_Summer_Olympics "Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics") event.[\[54]](#cite_note-54)[\[55]](#cite_note-55)[\[56]](#cite_note-56) On the last day of the Olympic Games on 21 August 2016, he won in a time of 2:08:44\. The runner up was Feyisa Lilesa (Ethiopia) in 2:09:54 and the bronze medal went to Galen Rupp (USA), doing his second marathon, crossing the finish line in 2:10:05\. When the halfway point after 21\.0975 km was reached, 37 men were within 10 seconds of the lead runner. The participants' field diminished to 3 lead runners shortly before 34 km. Kipchoge made his final move on silver medal winner Lilesa around 36 km into the race. He covered the first half of the race in 1:05:55 while doing the second half in 1:02:49, which amounts to a difference of more than 3 minutes, a negative split.[\[57]](#cite_note-57)[\[58]](#cite_note-Ingle-58) The winning gap between Kipchoge and Lilesa by 70 seconds was the largest victory margin since the [1972 Olympic marathon](/wiki/Athletics_at_the_1972_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_marathon "Athletics at the 1972 Summer Olympics – Men's marathon").[\[59]](#cite_note-59) Kipchoge's winning time of 2:08:44 was, as of August 2021, his slowest marathon time. One hundred fifty\-five runners started the race, the largest field in Olympic history; 140 of them finished the race.[\[60]](#cite_note-60)[\[61]](#cite_note-61) With this win, Kipchoge became the second Kenyan male after Sammy Wanjiru in [Beijing 2008](/wiki/Athletics_at_the_2008_Summer_Olympics "Athletics at the 2008 Summer Olympics") to win an Olympic marathon gold medal. At the same Olympics, the women's marathon was won by [Jemima Sumgong](/wiki/Jemima_Sumgong "Jemima Sumgong"), who became the first female Kenyan winner.[\[62]](#cite_note-62)[\[58]](#cite_note-Ingle-58)

On 20 November 2016, Kipchoge ran in the Airtel [Delhi Half Marathon](/wiki/Delhi_Half_Marathon "Delhi Half Marathon"), winning the race, clocking a time of 59:44\.[\[63]](#cite_note-63)

### 2017

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Eliud_Kipchoge&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: 2017")]
Further information: [Breaking2](/wiki/Breaking2 "Breaking2")
On 6 May, Kipchoge, along with Zersenay Tadese (then world record holder in the half marathon) and [Lelisa Desisa](/wiki/Lelisa_Desisa "Lelisa Desisa") (2\-time Boston Marathon winner), attempted the first sub\-two\-hour assisted marathon in the Nike [Breaking2](/wiki/Breaking2 "Breaking2") project on the [Monza](/wiki/Monza "Monza") [Formula 1 racetrack](/wiki/Autodromo_Nazionale_Monza "Autodromo Nazionale Monza") near [Milan](/wiki/Milan "Milan"), Italy. All three runners ran a test 2 months before the attempt. The target time was 1 hour for a half Marathon. Kipchoge finished first in 59:17\. The course was measured at 2400 m per lap.[\[64]](#cite_note-64) During the 2\-hour attempt, the runners were paced by a lead car and 30 supporting pacers joining in stages (both considered illegal under [IAAF](/wiki/IAAF "IAAF") rules).[\[65]](#cite_note-veconomist-65) The race started at 5:45h local time on the 2\.4 km track. Kipchoge finished in 2:00:25, while the other two had to slow and finished far behind.[\[66]](#cite_note-66) The runners planned even 14:13 5k splits to break 2 hours. His 5k splits were: 14:14, 14:07, 14:13, 14:15, 14:14, 14:17, 14:17, 14:27, and 6:20 to finish.[\[67]](#cite_note-67) The 5k split times from 25k and further would be world records: 25k in 1:11:03, 30k in 1:25:20, 35k in 1:39:37, 40k in 1:54:04\.

On 24 September, he won the [2017 Berlin Marathon](/wiki/2017_Berlin_Marathon "2017 Berlin Marathon") in a time of 2:03:32\.[\[68]](#cite_note-68) In rainy conditions, he finished 14 seconds ahead of [Guye Adola](/wiki/Guye_Adola "Guye Adola") who ran his first marathon, and set the fastest marathon debut ever.[\[69]](#cite_note-69) Former marathon world record holder Wilson Kipsang and 2016 winner Kenenisa Bekele failed to finish.[\[70]](#cite_note-70)[\[71]](#cite_note-71)

### 2018

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Eliud_Kipchoge&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: 2018")]
Kipchoge won the [London Marathon](/wiki/2018_London_Marathon "2018 London Marathon") against a field that included [Mo Farah](/wiki/Mo_Farah "Mo Farah"), Kenenisa Bekele, and defending champion [Daniel Wanjiru](/wiki/Daniel_Wanjiru "Daniel Wanjiru").[\[72]](#cite_note-72)[\[73]](#cite_note-73)[\[74]](#cite_note-74)[\[75]](#cite_note-75)[\[76]](#cite_note-76)

#### 2018 Berlin and first world marathon record

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Eliud_Kipchoge&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: 2018 Berlin and first world marathon record")]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Eliud_Kipchoge_at_Berlin_Marathon_2018_04.jpg/220px-Eliud_Kipchoge_at_Berlin_Marathon_2018_04.jpg)](/wiki/File:Eliud_Kipchoge_at_Berlin_Marathon_2018_04.jpg)

Eliud Kipchoge (L) and his three [pacers](/wiki/Pacemaker_(running) "Pacemaker (running)") (R) about 30 minutes into the run en route to the marathon world record in 2018\. He is shown a few seconds before crossing the [river Spree](/wiki/Spree_(river) "Spree (river)").

> "A 2:01:39 in the Marathon is like a Mars landing for Space travel."

*[Neue Zürcher Zeitung](/wiki/Neue_Z%C3%BCrcher_Zeitung "Neue Zürcher Zeitung")*[\[77]](#cite_note-77)

> "Whatever happens, this will surely go down as Kipchoge's crowning glory, his marathon opus. It would be no surprise if his record stood for a generation unless, of course, he himself has other ideas."

*[The Guardian](/wiki/The_Guardian "The Guardian")*[\[78]](#cite_note-78)

> "In an astonishing performance at the 2018 BMW Berlin Marathon, Kipchoge took marathoning into a new stratosphere by clocking 2:01:39 – the first man ever under 2:02, and a full 78 seconds faster than Dennis Kimetto's four\-year\-old world record.
>
>
> It was a performance so far superior to anything we've seen before that comparing it to another marathon feels inadequate. This was Wilt Chamberlain's 100\-point game in basketball, Usain Bolt's 9\.58 in the 100\-meter dash.
>
>
> Kipchoge's splits – 1:01:06 for the first half, a ridiculous 1:00:33 for his second half – sound made up. But they were real, and they were spectacular."

*[LetsRun.com](/wiki/LetsRun.com "LetsRun.com")*[\[79]](#cite_note-79)

On 16 September, Kipchoge won the [2018 Berlin Marathon](/wiki/2018_Berlin_Marathon "2018 Berlin Marathon") in a time of 2:01:39, breaking the previous world record by 1 minute and 18 seconds (2:02:57 set by fellow countryman Dennis Kimetto at the Berlin Marathon in 2014\). It was the greatest improvement in a marathon world record time since 1967\.[\[80]](#cite_note-80) He finished 4:43 min ahead of second\-placed fellow Kenyan Amos Kipruto. The world record holder from 2013, Wilson Kipsang of Kenya, came in third at 2:06:48\.[\[81]](#cite_note-81)[\[82]](#cite_note-82) It was the 11th world record set at the Berlin Marathon.[\[49]](#cite_note-BerlinRecords-49)

#### 2018 accolades

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Eliud_Kipchoge&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: 2018 accolades")]
Following his performances in the 2018 season, Kipchoge received numerous accolades and awards. He was named [IAAF World Athlete of the Year](/wiki/IAAF_World_Athlete_of_the_Year "IAAF World Athlete of the Year") together with [Caterine Ibargüen](/wiki/Caterine_Ibarg%C3%BCen "Caterine Ibargüen"), who received the female World Athlete of the Year award.[\[83]](#cite_note-83) On 11 January 2019, Kipchoge was named the 2018 Sportsman of the Year at the [Kenyan Sports Personality of the Year](/wiki/Kenyan_Sports_Personality_of_the_Year "Kenyan Sports Personality of the Year") Awards in [Mombasa](/wiki/Mombasa "Mombasa"), Kenya.[\[84]](#cite_note-84)

### 2019

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Eliud_Kipchoge&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: 2019")]
Kipchoge won the [2019 London Marathon](/wiki/2019_London_Marathon "2019 London Marathon") in a time of 2:02:37, the second fastest marathon ever at that time, behind his 2018 Berlin Marathon win.[\[85]](#cite_note-85) He became the first man to win the event four times and set a new course record, beating his own 2016 London Marathon best by 28 seconds.[\[86]](#cite_note-86) The lead runner passed the half marathon mark in 1:01:37\.[\[87]](#cite_note-87) [Mosinet Geremew](/wiki/Mosinet_Geremew "Mosinet Geremew") (Ethiopia) finished as the runner up in 2:02:55 and [Mule Wasihun](/wiki/Mule_Wasihun "Mule Wasihun") (Ethiopia) came in third place in 2:03:16\.[\[5]](#cite_note-News-5) The British runner [Mo Farah](/wiki/Mo_Farah "Mo Farah"), a four\-time Olympic gold medalist and a pre\-race favourite, finished 5th.[\[88]](#cite_note-88)

#### Ineos 1:59 Challenge

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Eliud_Kipchoge&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Ineos 1:59 Challenge")]
Further information: [Ineos 1:59 Challenge](/wiki/Ineos_1:59_Challenge "Ineos 1:59 Challenge")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Wikinews-logo.svg/40px-Wikinews-logo.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Wikinews-logo.svg)
Wikinews has related news:
* [Eliud Kipchoge of Kenya runs marathon under two hours](https://en.wikinews.org/wiki/Eliud_Kipchoge_of_Kenya_runs_marathon_under_two_hours "wikinews:Eliud Kipchoge of Kenya runs marathon under two hours")

In May 2019, a few days after his London Marathon win, Kipchoge announced another take on the sub\-two\-hour marathon, named the [Ineos 1:59 Challenge](/wiki/Ineos_1:59_Challenge "Ineos 1:59 Challenge"). On 12 October 2019 in [Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna")'s [Prater](/wiki/Prater "Prater") park, he ran 4\.4 laps of the Hauptallee in 1:59:40, becoming the first person in recorded history to break the two\-hour barrier over a marathon distance.[\[89]](#cite_note-89)[\[90]](#cite_note-90)[\[91]](#cite_note-91)

The effort did not count as a new world record under IAAF rules due to the setup of the challenge. Specifically, it was not an open event; Kipchoge was handed fluids by his support team throughout; the run featured a pace car and included rotating teams of other runners pacing Kipchoge in a formation designed to reduce wind resistance and maximise efficiency.[\[92]](#cite_note-92)[\[93]](#cite_note-93) The achievement was recognised by [Guinness World Records](/wiki/Guinness_World_Records "Guinness World Records") with the titles 'Fastest marathon distance (male)' and 'First marathon distance run under two hours'.[\[94]](#cite_note-94)[\[95]](#cite_note-95)

### 2020

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Eliud_Kipchoge&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: 2020")]
Kipchoge placed 8th in the [2020 London Marathon](/wiki/2020_London_Marathon "2020 London Marathon") in October with a time of 2:06:49, the lowest finish of his marathoning career.[\[7]](#cite_note-runningmagazine.ca-7)

### 2021

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Eliud_Kipchoge&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: 2021")]
In preparation for the delayed [2020 Tokyo Olympic Games](/wiki/Athletics_at_the_2020_Summer_Olympics "Athletics at the 2020 Summer Olympics"), he won the *NN Mission Marathon*, which was held at [Enschede Airport Twente](/wiki/Enschede_Airport_Twente "Enschede Airport Twente") in the Netherlands on 18 April 2021 in a time of 2:04:30\. Jonathan Korir finished as the runner up with a personal best of 2:06:40\.[\[96]](#cite_note-96)

Kipchoge successfully defended his title from the Rio Olympics by winning the gold medal in the men's marathon at the Tokyo Games in a time of 2:08:38, becoming only the third person to successfully defend their gold medal in the men's marathon, after [Abebe Bikila](/wiki/Abebe_Bikila "Abebe Bikila") in 1960 and 1964, and [Waldemar Cierpinski](/wiki/Waldemar_Cierpinski "Waldemar Cierpinski") in 1976 and 1980\.[\[97]](#cite_note-97) He was the favourite to win and attacked around the 30 km mark, looking back only once afterwards. He won by 80 seconds, the largest margin in 49 years.[\[98]](#cite_note-98) The silver medal went to [Abdi Nageeye](/wiki/Abdi_Nageeye "Abdi Nageeye") (Netherlands), while [Bashir Abdi](/wiki/Bashir_Abdi "Bashir Abdi") (Belgium) came in third for a bronze medal with 2:10:00\. Kipchoge was the oldest Olympic marathon winner since [Carlos Lopes](/wiki/Carlos_Lopes "Carlos Lopes") won in 1984 at the age of 37\. The run was staged 500 miles north of Tokyo in [Sapporo](/wiki/Sapporo "Sapporo"), with 106 runners participating.[\[99]](#cite_note-99) A documentary on the Ineos 1:59 Challenge, titled *[Kipchoge: The Last Milestone](/wiki/Kipchoge:_The_Last_Milestone "Kipchoge: The Last Milestone")*, was released digitally [on\-demand](/wiki/Video_on_demand "Video on demand") on 24 August 2021\.

### 2022

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Eliud_Kipchoge&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: 2022")]
On 20 January, Kipchoge announced his desire to win all six [World Marathon Majors](/wiki/World_Marathon_Majors "World Marathon Majors") (he had already won three, the London, Berlin, and Chicago marathons by that time). This was followed up by an announcement on 18 February that he would be participating in the [2021 Tokyo Marathon](/wiki/2021_Tokyo_Marathon "2021 Tokyo Marathon") (which took place on 6 March 2022 due to [COVID\-19](/wiki/COVID-19 "COVID-19") restrictions in 2021\) and that the majority of his recent training has been dedicated towards this goal.[\[100]](#cite_note-100) He won the Tokyo Marathon with a time of 2:02:40 – a course and all\-comers' record. [Amos Kipruto](/wiki/Amos_Kipruto "Amos Kipruto") of Kenya finished second with a personal best of 2:03:13, and [Tamirat Tola](/wiki/Tamirat_Tola "Tamirat Tola") from Ethiopia came in third in a time of 2:04:14\.[\[101]](#cite_note-101)

#### 2022 Berlin and second world marathon record

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Eliud_Kipchoge&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: 2022 Berlin and second world marathon record")]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Berlin_Marathon_2022_Eliud_Kipchoge_km_14%2C5.jpg/168px-Berlin_Marathon_2022_Eliud_Kipchoge_km_14%2C5.jpg)](/wiki/File:Berlin_Marathon_2022_Eliud_Kipchoge_km_14,5.jpg)Kipchoge (back center) about 14\.5 km (9\.0 mi) into the race, behind pacemakers (in striped gear).[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Eliud_Kipchoge_in_Berlin.jpg/176px-Eliud_Kipchoge_in_Berlin.jpg)](/wiki/File:Eliud_Kipchoge_in_Berlin.jpg)Eliud at the [2022 Berlin Marathon](/wiki/2022_Berlin_Marathon "2022 Berlin Marathon").
On 25 September, Kipchoge won the [Berlin Marathon](/wiki/2022_Berlin_Marathon "2022 Berlin Marathon") decisively in a time of 2:01:09, beating by 30 seconds his own previous world record, which he set on the same course in 2018\. With his fourth victory in Berlin, he equalled the record achievement of [Haile Gebrselassie](/wiki/Haile_Gebrselassie "Haile Gebrselassie"). He finished 4:49 min ahead of second\-placed compatriot [Mark Korir](/wiki/Mark_Korir "Mark Korir") while Ethiopia's Tadu Abate took third place with a time of 2:06:28\. Kipchoge achieved halfway in 59:51 which, being at the time, the fastest split in marathon history, would have been a world record in the standalone half\-marathon in 1993, and was only 26 seconds off his best in that distance. He slowed down later with second half in 61:18\.[\[102]](#cite_note-102)[\[103]](#cite_note-103)[\[104]](#cite_note-104)[\[105]](#cite_note-105) It was the eighth time in a row that men's record was set in Berlin and 12th record there overall.[\[106]](#cite_note-106)[\[49]](#cite_note-BerlinRecords-49)

### 2023–present

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Eliud_Kipchoge&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: 2023–present")]
At the [2023 Boston Marathon](/wiki/2023_Boston_Marathon "2023 Boston Marathon"), Kipchoge aimed to win his fifth of the six major marathons. However, after missing his water bottle and due to a left leg problem,[\[107]](#cite_note-107)[\[108]](#cite_note-108) the 38\-year\-old was unable to stay with the lead group on a hilly section after the 30 km mark. He suffered the third defeat of his marathon career, finishing sixth with a time of 2:09:23\. [Evans Chebet](/wiki/Evans_Chebet "Evans Chebet") was the winner in 2:05:54, successfully defending his title.[\[109]](#cite_note-109) At the [2023 Berlin Marathon](/wiki/2023_Berlin_Marathon "2023 Berlin Marathon"), his first race since the Boston defeat, he won the race for a record fifth time, finishing at 2:02:42\. He ran alone from 32 kilometers (20 miles) onward after Ethiopia's Derseh Kindie dropped away, but fell short of breaking his own world record he set the previous year. With the victory, Kipchoge became the first man in history to win the Berlin Marathon five times, having already won in 2015, 2017, 2018 and 2022\.

Kipchoge failed to finish the marathon for the first time in his career when defending his gold medal at the [2024 Paris Olympics](/wiki/2024_Summer_Olympics "2024 Summer Olympics"), dropping out of the race after around 30 km citing discomfort around his waist. He later told reporters that he would not compete at another Olympic Games. "You will see me in a different way, maybe giving people motivation, but I will not run," he said when asked about the prospects of competing in [Los Angeles in 2028](/wiki/2028_Summer_Olympics "2028 Summer Olympics"). "I need to go back, sit down, try to figure my 21 years of running at high level. I need to evolve and feature in other things," he added.[\[110]](#cite_note-110) Despite the downfall, President William Ruto still recognized Kipchoge as a legend. "I know how people were disappointed. Many people I know made a lot of comments, 'How could Eliud not finish?' But Eliud we celebrate you. You have held our flag high," [Ruto said](https://classic105.com/latest/2024-08-15-president-rutos-message-to-eliud-kipchoge-after-olympics-misfortune/).
